name: Pamplona
fun_fact: Fun fact: While Pamplona is world-famous for the Running of the Bulls during San Ferm√≠n (dating back 400+ years), the tradition started simply because butchers needed to move bulls from ranches to the city center. Young butchers began racing in front of the bulls to speed them up - and it turned into one of the world's most thrilling festivals. Women were banned until 1974!

hero_dishes.name: Piquillo Peppers (Pimientos del Piquillo)
hero_dishes.description: Sweet, delicate red peppers with intense flavor, roasted and served with olive oil and garlic, or stuffed with meat, fish, or cod
hero_dishes.origin_story: Known as the 'red gold' of Navarran allotments with a protected designation of origin. Produced mainly in La Ribera district, these autumn-harvested peppers have an unmistakable flavor. They combine perfectly with cod (bacalao) and represent one of Navarra's most prestigious agricultural products.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurante Europa (Michelin-starred since 1993) near Plaza del Castillo offers exquisite treatment of seasonal piquillo peppers. Traditional restaurants throughout the Old Town feature them as starters or main courses.

hero_dishes.name: Cordero al Chilindr√≥n
hero_dishes.description: Tender lamb stew made with tomatoes, onions, garlic, dried nora peppers, white wine, lemon peel, and parsley, served in earthenware
hero_dishes.origin_story: For centuries, this dish was eaten solely during main festivals in Navarra. Today it's part of daily cooking throughout the region. Made from lamb leg or shoulder saut√©ed until everything melds together, traditionally served in the same clay dish it was cooked in. Often served Sundays at lunchtime at traditional restaurants, accompanied by boiled or fried potatoes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Enekorri in Riezu (30+ years of expertise, blends traditional Navarrese with innovation) and El Burladero near Plaza de Toros serve authentic versions. Restaurante Anttonenea highlights quality lamb shoulder.

hero_dishes.name: Ajoarriero (Bacalao Ajoarriero)
hero_dishes.description: Desalted cod stewed with red and green piquillo peppers, tomatoes, onions, garlic, choricero peppers, and white wine, served with bread and hard-boiled egg
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional recipe is shared with neighboring La Rioja and has Basque origins but has been widely embraced in Navarra. The name comes from the arriero (muleteer) tradition - hardy travelers who needed filling, flavorful meals on the road.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional bodeg√≥n-style restaurants in the Old Town. Restaurant Baserriberri offers modern creative takes on classic dishes like this.

hero_dishes.name: Menestra de Verduras
hero_dishes.description: Star vegetable stew from Navarran allotments featuring asparagus, artichokes, peas, and broad beans
hero_dishes.origin_story: Showcases the excellent vegetables from La Ribera that Navarra is famous for. The region's cardoon, artichokes, fresh white beans, asparagus, and piquillo peppers are prized throughout Spain. This dish celebrates Navarra's agricultural bounty.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Mandarra de La Ramos (sleek tapas bar with chef dedicated to locally-sourced produce) and fine dining spots like Restaurante Europa

hero_dishes.name: Pintxos
hero_dishes.description: Small bites on bread, Pamplona's version of Basque tapas - a culinary institution and social event
hero_dishes.origin_story: Pintxos are more than food in Pamplona - they're a way of experiencing life with friends, family, and strangers. The pintxos route spans the Old Town and all neighborhoods, making it the most popular way to eat out. It's impossible to cover the whole route because there are so many bars.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Three gastronomic routes run through the city: The Camino route, the Encierro route, and the Green route. Bars throughout the historic center, especially around Plaza del Castillo

signature_drinks.name: Pachar√°n (Patxaran)
signature_drinks.description: Reddish digestif liqueur (30% alcohol) made from sloe berries macerated in anisette and spices for months
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold after meals as a stomach tonic. For centuries, Navarrans relied on pachar√°n as a home remedy for stomach pains, nausea, and even hangovers. Records show it was served at the wedding of Gonofre de Navarre in 1415, and Queen Blanca I took it for medicinal purposes in 1441. Though more sangria and beer flow during San Ferm√≠n now, pachar√°n is the drink most closely associated with the festival - like Pimms at Wimbledon. Once looked down upon as blue-collar, it's now enjoyed by everyone from bullrunners to discriminating winemakers. Must contain no artificial flavorings under the official D.O. Navarra designation.

signature_drinks.name: Navarra Wine (D.O. Navarra)
signature_drinks.description: Red wines (Tempranillo, Garnacha, Graciano, Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon) and whites (Chardonnay, Viura, Moscatel, Malvas√≠a), especially famous for rosado (ros√©)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The appellation benefits from the Bay of Biscay, Pyrenees influence, and temperate Ebro valley climate. Five zones: Baja Montana, Ribera Alta, Ribera Baja, Tierra Estella, Valdizarbe. Traditionally linked with ros√© wine - Garnacha tops the list. Paired with lamb chilindr√≥n, piquillo peppers, and pintxos.

signature_drinks.name: Kalimotxos
signature_drinks.description: Traditional beverage mixing red wine with cola, served over ice
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Order this to feel like a real Navarran local - a uniquely Spanish combination popular at festivals and casual gatherings

signature_drinks.name: Craft Beer and Cider
signature_drinks.description: Locally produced craft beers and traditional Basque-style cider
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A fantastic array of craft beers available throughout Pamplona. Cider drinking is part of local custom, reflecting Basque influence on Navarra's beverage culture.

food_culture_notes: Pintxos culture is a culinary institution and social event - impossible to cover the whole route
The region showcases a mix of Spanish, Basque, and French cultural influences
Navarra is famous for vegetables from La Ribera: cardoon, artichokes, beans, asparagus, piquillo peppers
Foie gras, mushrooms, and flavorful meats pair with D.O. Navarre and Rioja wines
Traditional desserts: cheese, curd (cuajada), rolled wafer sticks, leche frita (fried milk and flour)
One restaurant near Pamplona has two Michelin stars and a green star - an emblem of Navarran cooking
Txistorra (chistorra) sausage typical to Navarre, Aragon, and Basque Country - pork/beef with garlic and paprika
